titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mrs. W.K. Clifford Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:10

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Plays, cinema scenarios, correspondence, notes, clippings and reviews of Mrs. W.K. Clifford, d. 1929 (also known as Lucy Clifford and John Inglis).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from John Hart on the Edwin J. Beinecke and Edith and Richard French funds, 2005 and 2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 17: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mrs. W.K. Clifford Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mrs. W.K. Clifford Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Mrs. W.K. Clifford, d. 1929
bioghist.p: Mrs. W[illiam] K[ingdon] Clifford (born Sophia Lucy Jane Lane in a year variously recorded as 1846 or 1853) wrote essays, reviews, short stories, novels, plays and cinema scenarios. She is also remembered for her friendship with literary figures such as George Eliot, Henry James and Rudyard Kipling. Some of Clifford's writings were published anonymously or under her initials "L.C." (especially before 1891) or under pseudonyms. Among Clifford's novels are Mrs. Keith's Crime: A Record (1885), Love-Letters of a Worldly Woman (1891), and Aunt Anne (1892). She also wrote successfully for a young audience; her children's books include Children Busy, Children Glad, Children Naughty, Children Sad (1881) and Anyhow Stories, Moral and Otherwise (1882). Strong female characters were central to her writings and she addressed controversial issues including conflicted mother-child relationships, divorce and euthanasia.

Clifford's plays were published and produced in England, Europe and the United States. Her most successful play was The Likeness of the Night (1900). Many of her plays were based on her own short stories and novels. She also wrote cinema adaptations of her short stories and plays. At least two films were produced from her adaptations: The Likeness of the Night (1922), directed by Percy Nash and Eve's Lover (1925), directed by Roy Del Ruth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mrs. W.K. Clifford Papers consist of writings, correspondence, personal papers (including photographs) and collected reviews and clippings. Among the writings are two works by Clifford's daughters: a poem by Ethel Clifford (Lady Dilke) and an essay by Margaret Clifford. There are also pseudonymous writings by Mrs. Clifford under the names of Leonard Carter, John Inglis, John Marison and Gerard Mountjoy. Two of the works in the papers are co-authored.

The papers chiefly contain Clifford's dramatic writing, including playscripts and cinematic adaptations of her short stories and plays. The writings document the stages of development of playscripts and cinema scenarios from synopses to full scripts. Most of the writings are typescripts corrected by Clifford.The correspondence documents Clifford's professional relationships with publishers, producers and readers. There is a very small amount of personal correspondence with family members. The personal papers include diaries, financial records, work books, Clifford's will, a few photographs of Clifford and one photograph of Clifford's father. The papers also contain clippings and reviews relating to Clifford's life and work. Most of these clippings were sent to Clifford by subscription services and one folder of biographical clippings was collected after her death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four series: Correspondence, Writings, Personal Papers, Reviews and Clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence mostly relates to Clifford's management of the publishing and production of her works. Some correspondence is from readers and contains admiration or criticism of her work. There is also a small amount of personal correspondence with her family members and friends, including two letters from her grandson John while he was at school.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two subseries: Professional and Personal. The Professional correspondence is further divided into Correspondence regarding specific works (which follows Clifford's own arrangement in envelopes according to subject) and Other professional correspondence, which is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. Personal correspondence is arranged alphabetically. One folder of letters with illegible signatures is filed at the end of Professional (by correspondent). Most of the correspondence is incoming, although there is one folder of outgoing and one folder of third party.
Two letters can also be found in Series III. Personal Papers. These letters (one from Helge A. Johnson, another from J.T. Grein) are pasted or glued into notebooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: General correspondence A-Z is filed after general correspondence by name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in this series relates primarily to Clifford's dramatic works. The multiple copies of many works reflect different stages in the writing process, different productions, or holograph annotations by Clifford. The material includes completed scripts, synopses (brief prose summaries) and scenarios (outlines of scripts).

Many of the plays and cinema scenarios are adaptations of other works by Clifford. For example, the play The New Mother is based on a short story of the same name; the play A Supreme Moment is based on two acts of the play The Singer of Dreams ; the cinema scenario Dead Sea Fruit is based on the novel Love Letters of a Worldly Woman . These relationships of adaptation have been noted only where they are clear from annotations on the typescripts and the account should not be considered exhaustive.

The Plays subseries consists of typescripts and published versions of plays as well as associated material such as contracts, broadsides and programs. Most typescripts are corrected in Clifford's hand and some are signed. Few are dated. Some of the printed versions have no publication information.

The Cinema Scenarios subseries consists of typescript adaptations of Clifford's short stories, novels and plays as well as one contract with Warner Bros. to produce Eve's Lover . Clifford noted that she did not proceed with the contract because of her concern that Warner Bros. would claim full dramatic rights to the story.
The Songs and Poems subseries includes the lyrics for one song, one typescript poem by Clifford, and one typescript poem by her daughter Ethel Clifford (Lady Dilke).

The Other Writings subseries contains Clifford's prose writing, essays and lectures as well as one essay by Clifford's daughter Margaret Clifford. While Mrs. W.K.Clifford was a prolific novelist and short story writer, this collection contains little of her prose writing. The exception is material relating to a compilation of her short stories entitled The Last Touches .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four subseries: Plays, Cinema Scenarios, Songs and Poems, and Other Writings. Within each subseries, material is arranged by title of work. Untitled manuscripts are filed at the end of each subseries. Several of the works have multiple or working titles, as indicated in the folder notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal papers document Clifford's activities and relationships through her diaries, her personal business through her workbooks, and her creative work through her notebooks. Other materials include several photographs of Clifford, one photograph of John Brandford Lane, one photograph of John Lane, a note to literary executors, Clifford's will and several cashed checks signed by W.K. Clifford.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Diaries are arranged chronologically; remaining material is arranged by format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains signed letter from Helge A. Johnson, 1924 Jun 3

did.unittitle: Cashed checks signed by W.K. Clifford
Photograph and documents related to Sir John Brandford Lane

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV consists of clippings from magazines, newspapers and journals. Most are reviews of Clifford's stories, novels and plays. Many of them were sent to her by clipping services based on subscriptions. Some clippings are not full reviews but merely refer to a work.

In addition to the clippings collected by Clifford, there is one folder of obituaries and death notices devoted to her. It is not known who collected these notices and added them to Clifford's papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Reviews and Clippings are arranged by title of work with the following exceptions: two folders of contain material which does not clearly relate to a single work; one folder contains a biographical announcement about Clifford; one folder contains obituaries and death notices devoted to Clifford. The final folder of the series contains empty envelopes annotated by Clifford. She used these envelopes to arrange her clippings and correspondence but they were empty when the papers were transferred to the Beinecke Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 17, Restricted Fragile, contains fragile originals. The material is arranged in folder order and may be seen only with the permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies or photographic prints have been substituted in the main files for reference use.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
